panels.description: Apdex is a measure of requests that complete within a tolerable period of time for the service. Higher is better.

seriesOverrides.alias: /6h Degradation SLO \(5% of monthly error budget\).*/
/1h Outage SLO \(2% of monthly error budget\).*/

targets.legendFormat: 6h Degradation SLO (5% of monthly error budget)
1h Outage SLO (2% of monthly error budget)

panels.title: redis-cluster-chat-cache Service Apdex

targets.expr:
sum(
  label_replace(
    vector(0) and on() (gitlab_service_apdex:ratio_1h{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"}),
    "period", "na", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(1) and on () (gitlab_service_apdex:ratio_5m{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (14.4 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="",monitor="global",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"})))),
    "period", "5m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(2) and on () (gitlab_service_apdex:ratio_1h{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (14.4 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="",monitor="global",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"})))),
    "period", "1h", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(4) and on () (gitlab_service_apdex:ratio_30m{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (6 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="",monitor="global",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"})))),
    "period", "30m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(8) and on () (gitlab_service_apdex:ratio_6h{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (6 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="",monitor="global",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"})))),
    "period", "6h", "", ""
  )
)

panels.title: redis-cluster-chat-cache Service Error Ratio

targets.expr:
sum (
  label_replace(
    vector(0) and on() (gitlab_service_errors:ratio_1h{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"}),
    "period", "na", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(1) and on() (gitlab_service_errors:ratio_5m{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"} > on(tier, type) group_left() (14.4 * slo:max:events:gitlab_service_errors:ratio{component="",monitor="global",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"})),
    "period", "5m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(2) and on() (gitlab_service_errors:ratio_1h{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"} > on(tier, type) group_left() (14.4 * slo:max:events:gitlab_service_errors:ratio{component="",monitor="global",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"})),
    "period", "1h", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(4) and on() (gitlab_service_errors:ratio_30m{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"} > on(tier, type) group_left() (6 * slo:max:events:gitlab_service_errors:ratio{component="",monitor="global",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"})),
    "period", "30m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(8) and on() (gitlab_service_errors:ratio_6h{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"} > on(tier, type) group_left() (6 * slo:max:events:gitlab_service_errors:ratio{component="",monitor="global",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"})),
    "period", "6h", "", ""
  )
)

panels.description: The operation rate is the sum total of all requests being handle for all components within this service. Note that a single user request can lead to requests to multiple components. Higher is busier.

panels.content:
### Description

Operations on the Redis primary for Redis Cluster Chat Cache instance.



### Observability Tools

* [üìñ Kibana: Redis logs](https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/app/kibana#/discover?_a=(columns:!(json.hostname,json.redis_message),filters:!((meta:(index:'AWSQX_Vf93rHTYrsexmk',key:json.type.keyword,params:'redis-cluster-chat-cache',type:phrase),query:(match:(json.type.keyword:(query:'redis-cluster-chat-cache',type:phrase)))),(meta:(index:'AWSQX_Vf93rHTYrsexmk',key:json.type,params:'redis-cluster-chat-cache',type:phrase),query:(match:(json.type:(query:'redis-cluster-chat-cache',type:phrase))))),index:'AWSQX_Vf93rHTYrsexmk')&_g=(time:(from:'${__from:date:iso}',to:'${__to:date:iso}')))

panels.title: rails_redis_client SLI Apdex

sum(
  label_replace(
    vector(0) and on() (gitlab_component_apdex:ratio_1h{component="rails_redis_client",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"}),
    "period", "na", "", ""

  or

    vector(1) and on () (gitlab_component_apdex:ratio_5m{component="rails_redis_client",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (14.4 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="rails_redis_client",monitor="global",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"})))),

panels.content:
### Description

Aggregation of all Redis Cluster Chat Cache operations issued from the Rails codebase
through `Gitlab::Redis::Wrapper` subclasses.

panels.description: Network utilization
panels.title: redis Deployment: Network IO

panels.description:
Ratio of requested CPU resources from allocatable resources.
Ideally we have requests utilization close to 100%. Values are
below 100% typically because pods do not fit well on nodes or
because we might be bound by memory requests already.
panels.title: Node CPU Requests Utilization

panels.description:
Ratio of requested Memory resources from allocatable resources.
Ideally we have requests utilization close to 100%. Values are
below 100% typically because pods do not fit well on nodes or
because we might be bound by CPU requests already.
panels.title: Node Memory Requests Utilization

panels.description:
This resource measures average CPU utilization across an all cores in a service fleet.
If it is becoming saturated, it may indicate that the fleet needs
horizontal or vertical scaling.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      1 - avg by (environment, tier, type, stage, shard) (
        rate(node_cpu_seconds_total{mode="idle", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"}[5m])
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: cpu component saturation: Average Service CPU Utilization

panels.description:
Disk inode utilization per device per node.

If this is too high, its possible that a directory is filling up with
files. Consider logging in an checking temp directories for large numbers
of files
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn, device) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      1 - (
        node_filesystem_files_free{fstype=~"(ext.|xfs)", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"}
        /
        node_filesystem_files{fstype=~"(ext.|xfs)", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"}
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: disk_inodes component saturation: Disk inode Utilization per Device per Node

panels.description:
Disk space utilization per device per node.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn, device) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      (
        1 - node_filesystem_avail_bytes{fstype=~"ext.|xfs", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"} / node_filesystem_size_bytes{fstype=~"ext.|xfs", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"}
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: disk_space component saturation: Disk Space Utilization per Device per Node

panels.description:
Kubernetes containers are allocated a share of CPU. Configured using resource requests.

This is the amount of CPU that a container should always have available,
though it can briefly utilize more. However, if a lot of pods on the same
host exceed their requested CPU the container could be throttled earlier.

This monitors utilization/allocated requests over a 1 hour period, and takes
the 99th quantile of that utilization percentage in that period.
We want the worst case to be around 80%-90% utilization,
meaning we've sized the container correctly. If utilization is much higher than that
the container could already be throttled because the host is overused, if it
is much lower, then we could be underutilizing a host.

This saturation point is only used for capacity planning.
The burst utilization of a CPU is monitored and alerted upon using the
`kube_container_cpu_limit` saturation point.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    quantile by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, pod, container) (
  0.99,
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      sum by (environment, tier, type, stage, shard, pod, container) (
        rate(container_cpu_usage_seconds_total:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"}[1h])
      )
      /
      sum by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, pod, container) (
        kube_pod_container_resource_requests:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", resource="cpu", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"}
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: kube_container_cpu component saturation: Kube Container CPU Utilization

panels.description:
Kubernetes containers can have a limit configured on how much CPU they can consume in
a burst. If we are at this limit, exceeding the allocated requested resources, we
should consider revisting the container's HPA configuration.

When a container is utilizing CPU resources up-to it's configured limit for
extended periods of time, this could cause it and other running containers to be
throttled.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, pod, container) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      sum by (environment, tier, type, stage, shard, pod, container) (
        rate(container_cpu_usage_seconds_total:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"}[5m])
      )
      /
      sum by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, pod, container) (
        container_spec_cpu_quota:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"}
        /
        container_spec_cpu_period:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"}
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: kube_container_cpu_limit component saturation: Kube Container CPU over-utilization

panels.description:
This uses the working set size from cAdvisor for the cgroup's memory usage. That may
not be a good measure as it includes filesystem cache pages that are not necessarily
attributable to the application inside the cgroup, and are permitted to be evicted
instead of being OOM killed.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      container_memory_working_set_bytes:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"}
      /
      (container_spec_memory_limit_bytes:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"} > 0)
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: kube_container_memory component saturation: Kube Container Memory Utilization

panels.description:
The [Horizontal Pod Autoscaler](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/run-application/horizontal-pod-autoscale/)
automatically scales the number of Pods in a deployment based on metrics.

The Horizontal Pod Autoscaler has a configured upper maximum. When this
limit is reached, the HPA will not increase the number of pods and other
resource saturation (eg, CPU, memory) may occur.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, horizontalpodautoscaler, shard) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      kube_horizontalpodautoscaler_status_desired_replicas:labeled{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache", shard!~"database-throttled|elasticsearch|gitaly-throttled|urgent-authorized-projects|urgent-other", namespace!~"pubsubbeat"}
      /
      kube_horizontalpodautoscaler_spec_max_replicas:labeled{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache", shard!~"database-throttled|elasticsearch|gitaly-throttled|urgent-authorized-projects|urgent-other", namespace!~"pubsubbeat"}
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: kube_horizontalpodautoscaler_desired_replicas component saturation: Horizontal Pod Autoscaler Desired Replicas

panels.description:
This resource measures average CPU utilization across an all cores in the node pool for
a service fleet.

If it is becoming saturated, it may indicate that the fleet needs horizontal scaling.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      1 - avg by (environment, tier, type, stage, shard) (
        rate(node_cpu_seconds_total:labeled{mode="idle", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"}[5m])
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: kube_pool_cpu component saturation: Average Node Pool CPU Utilization

panels.description:
A GKE kubernetes node pool is close to it's maximum number of nodes.

The maximum is defined in terraform, via the `max_node_count` field of a node pool. The limit is per-zone, so for
single zone clusters the number of nodes will match the limit, for regional clusters, the limit is multiplied by
the number of zones the cluster is deployed over.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(env, environment, tier, type, stage, shard, cluster, label_pool, shard) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      count by (cluster, env, environment, label_pool, tier, type, stage, shard) (
        kube_node_labels:labeled{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"}
      )
      / on(cluster, env, environment, label_pool) group_left() (
        label_replace(
          terraform_report_google_cluster_node_pool_max_node_count,
          "label_pool", "$0", "pool_name", ".*"
        )
        * on(cluster, env, environment) group_left()
        count by (cluster, env, environment) (
          group by (cluster, env, environment, label_topology_kubernetes_io_zone) (
            kube_node_labels:labeled{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"}
          )
        )
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: kube_pool_max_nodes component saturation: Kube Pool Max Node Limit

panels.description:
Memory utilization per device per node.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      instance:node_memory_utilization:ratio{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"} or instance:node_memory_utilisation:ratio{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"}
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: memory component saturation: Memory Utilization per Node

panels.description:
Netfilter connection tracking table utilization per node.

When saturated, new connection attempts (incoming SYN packets) are dropped with no reply, leaving clients to slowly retry (and typically fail again) over the next several seconds.  When packets are being dropped due to this condition, kernel will log the event as: "nf_conntrack: table full, dropping packet".
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn, instance) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      max_over_time(node_nf_conntrack_entries{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"}[1m])
      /
      node_nf_conntrack_entries_limit{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"}
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: nf_conntrack_entries component saturation: conntrack Entries per Node

panels.description:
Measures the amount of scheduler waiting time that processes are waiting
to be scheduled, according to [`CPU Scheduling Metrics`](https://www.robustperception.io/cpu-scheduling-metrics-from-the-node-exporter).

A high value indicates that a node has more processes to be run than CPU time available
to handle them, and may lead to degraded responsiveness and performance from the application.

Additionally, it may indicate that the fleet is under-provisioned.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn, shard) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      avg without (cpu) (rate(node_schedstat_waiting_seconds_total{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"}[1h]))
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: node_schedstat_waiting component saturation: Node Scheduler Waiting Time

panels.description:
Open file descriptor utilization per instance.

Saturation on file descriptor limits may indicate a resource-descriptor leak in the application.

As a temporary fix, you may want to consider restarting the affected process.
 Lower is better.
panels.title: open_fds component saturation: Open file descriptor utilization per instance

panels.description:
Redis client utilization per node.

A redis server has a maximum number of clients that can connect. When this resource is saturated,
new clients may fail to connect.

More details at https://redis.io/topics/clients#maximum-number-of-clients
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn, instance, shard) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      max_over_time(redis_connected_clients{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"}[1m])
      /
      redis_config_maxclients{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"}
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: redis_cluster_clients component saturation: Redis Client Utilization per Node

panels.description:
Redis memory utilization per node.

As Redis memory saturates node memory, the likelyhood of OOM kills, possibly to the Redis process,
become more likely.

For caches, consider lowering the `maxmemory` setting in Redis. For non-caching Redis instances,
this has been caused in the past by credential stuffing, leading to large numbers of web sessions.

This threshold is kept deliberately low, since Redis RDB snapshots could consume a significant amount of memory,
especially when the rate of change in Redis is high, leading to copy-on-write consuming more memory than when the
rate-of-change is low.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn, instance, shard) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      max by (environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn, instance, shard) (
        label_replace(redis_memory_used_rss_bytes{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"}, "memtype", "rss","","")
        or
        label_replace(redis_memory_used_bytes{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"}, "memtype", "used","","")
      )
      /
      avg by (environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn, instance, shard) (
        node_memory_MemTotal_bytes{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"}
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: redis_cluster_memory component saturation: Redis Memory Utilization per Node

panels.description:
Redis Primary CPU Utilization per Node.

The core server of redis is single-threaded; this thread is only able to scale to full use of a single CPU on a given server.
When the primary Redis thread is saturated, major slowdowns should be expected across the application, so avoid if at all
possible.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn, instance, shard) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      sum by (environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn, instance, shard) (
        rate(
          namedprocess_namegroup_thread_cpu_seconds_total{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache", groupname="redis-server", threadname="redis-server"}[5m])
      )
      and on (fqdn) redis_instance_info{role="master"}
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: redis_cluster_primary_cpu component saturation: Redis Primary CPU Utilization per Node

panels.description:
Redis Secondary CPU Utilization per Node.

Redis is single-threaded. A single Redis server is only able to scale as far as a single CPU on a single host.
CPU saturation on a secondary is not as serious as critical as saturation on a primary, but could lead to
replication delays.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn, instance, shard) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      (
        rate(redis_cpu_user_seconds_total{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"}[5m])
        +
        rate(redis_cpu_sys_seconds_total{env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"}[5m])
      )
      and on (instance) redis_instance_info{role!="master"}
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: redis_secondary_cpu component saturation: Redis Secondary CPU Utilization per Node

panels.description:
This resource measures average CPU utilization across an all cores in a shard of a
service fleet. If it is becoming saturated, it may indicate that the
shard needs horizontal or vertical scaling.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, shard) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      1 - avg by (environment, tier, type, stage, shard, shard) (
        rate(node_cpu_seconds_total{mode="idle", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"}[5m])
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: shard_cpu component saturation: Average CPU Utilization per Shard

panels.description:
Average CPU utilization per Node.

If average CPU is saturated, it may indicate that a fleet is in need to horizontal or vertical scaling. It may also indicate
imbalances in load in a fleet.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, shard, fqdn) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      avg without(cpu, mode) (1 - rate(node_cpu_seconds_total{mode="idle", env="$environment",environment="$environment",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"}[5m]))
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: single_node_cpu component saturation: Average CPU Utilization per Node

panels.description: Blocked clients are waiting for a state change event using commands such as BLPOP. Blocked clients are not a sign of an issue on their own.
panels.title: Blocked Clients

targets.expr: sum(rate(redis_commands_total{environment="$environment",shard=~"$shard",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"}[$__interval]) and on (pod, fqdn) redis_instance_info{role="master", environment="$environment"} ) by (fqdn, pod)

sum(rate(redis_commands_total{environment="$environment",shard=~"$shard",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"}[$__interval]) and on (pod, fqdn) redis_instance_info{role="slave", environment="$environment"} ) by (fqdn, pod)

panels.description: redis is single-threaded. This graph shows maximum utilization across all cores on each host. Lower is better.
panels.title: Redis CPU per Node - Primary

panels.description: redis is single-threaded. This graph shows maximum utilization across all cores on each host. Lower is better.
panels.title: Redis CPU per Node - Replicas

panels.description: Redis holds all data in memory. Avoid memory saturation in Redis at all cost

seriesOverrides.alias: /6h Degradation SLO \(5% of monthly error budget\).*/
/1h Outage SLO \(2% of monthly error budget\).*/

targets.expr:
clamp_min(clamp_max(max(
  label_replace(redis_memory_used_rss_bytes{environment="$environment",shard=~"$shard",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"}, "memtype", "rss","","")
  or
  label_replace(redis_memory_used_bytes{environment="$environment",shard=~"$shard",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"}, "memtype", "used","","")
) by (type, stage, environment, fqdn)
/ on (fqdn) group_left
node_memory_MemTotal_bytes{environment="$environment",shard=~"$shard",type="redis-cluster-chat-cache"}
,1),0)

panels.title: Memory Saturation

panels.description: Depending on the memory allocator used, Redis may not return memory to the operating system at the same rate that applications release keys. RSS indicates the operating systems perspective of Redis memory usage. So, even if usage is low, if RSS is high, the OOM killer may terminate the Redis process
panels.title: Redis RSS Usage

panels.description: The fragmentation ratio in Redis should ideally be around 1.0 and generally below 1.5. The higher the value, the more wasted memory.
panels.title: Memory Fragmentation

options.content:
graph TD
  subgraph db
  redis-cluster-chat-cache
end

graph TD
  subgraph db
  redis-cluster-chat-cache
end

title: redis-cluster-chat-cache: Overview
